SPRING.</br>Lightly o'er the dewy fields,</br>Where her charms, gay nature yields,</br>Come, my Sylvia, hence away,</br>To invoke the vernal day.
Winter now, with gloomy train,</br>Holds no more his tyrant reign,—</br>Smiling SPRING, in chaplets gay,</br>Bids return the vernal day.
Hark!  my fair, in yonder grove,</br>Th' universal song is love—</br>Hark!  the sweet, — the love-taught lay</br>Hails aloud the vernal day.
View each blooming scene around!</br>Flora decks th' enamel'd ground;</br>Trees and plants their charms display,</br>To adorn the vernal day.
On each lawn, the playful lambs</br>Round about their fleecy dams,</br>Wanton, sport, and frisk and play,</br>At return of vernal day.—
Thus, each landscape, let's explore,</br>Till its term of beauty's o'er;</br>Then, my SYLVIA, hence away,</br>When no more is vernal day—
SUMMER.</br>To the side of murmuring stream,</br>Devoted to pleasure and ease,</br>Unseen by the sultry beam,</br>Except thro' the breaks of the trees.
Where woodbines with roses entwine,</br>Unpilfer'd their sweets by the bee;</br>But left for soft zephyr to join,</br>And waft them untainted to thee.
Around us may linnets appear,</br>Nor wish from their station to fly;</br>Whose strains let enrapture my ear,</br>But nothing, save SYLVIA, my eye.
Such be the retreat we frequent,</br>Tranquillity's blessings to prove:</br>Our guests be Delight and Content,</br>Our diet — soft pledges of love.
Thus bless'd, and embow'r'd from heat,</br>How transient will SUMMER be made!</br>Alas!  with a — sigh — I must greet</br>The time that dismantles our shade.

AUTUMN.</br>Now blighting winds, and mildew rain</br>Assail the beauties of the plain,</br>And lay their glories dead.—</br>O'er hill and dale — thro' wood and grove,</br>Where we, my fair, were wont to rove,</br>A leafy carpet's spread.

But blighting winds, not aught avail;</br>The fields unrob'd, deride the gale,</br>Destructive now now more:</br>For plenty bids the village smile,</br>And crowns the happy peasant's toil,</br>With Ceres' golden store.

And, in the sun's declining ray,</br>The vines their purple charms display,</br>Thro' leaves of russet hue:—</br>Hail!  latest product of the year,</br>Whose pow'r can fainting nature cheer,</br>And Winter's dreary view.
WINTER.</br>From regions of eternal snow,</br>Lo!  hoary WINTER seeks our land;</br>The mountain high — the valley low,</br>Alike declare his icy hand.
In shining fetters bound, the stream</br>No murmur lends to sooth the ear;</br>No warmth conveys the noon-tide beam,</br>Creation's torpid works to cheer.
No flow'r adorns the wasted plain,</br>Nor plants' fair verdure decks the lawn:</br>Grey mists usurp the wide domain,</br>And robe, with down, each tree and thorn.
The timid hare, from home to stray,</br>O'er woodland wild in search of fare</br>(Lest she her vestiges betray)</br>Kind instinct whispers to forbear.
Where sung the lark its matin strains,</br>The wint'ry fieldfare now is seen;</br>And dazzling snow makes white those plains,</br>Which once were dress'd in lovelier green.—
Thus diff'rent, SYLVIA, things appear;</br>In nature's scale ordain'd to move:—</br>Throughout the ever-rolling year,</br>The SEASONS change — but not my love.</br>
